719997f-a.text:
1899
Gay Street, north from Waverly Place. At the point where the "Wilson Whiskey" sign board appears, this short thoroughfare veers to the left to meet Christopher Street.  The distinctive building in the background is the Jefferson Market Court.

J. J. Corell, photo
P. L. Sperr Collection
NO REPORDUCTIONS
719997f-a.folder: Gay Street & Waverly Place, Manhattan, NY

724312f-a.text:
124 Waverly Place, south side, east of Sixth Ave., an old house remodelled with a north-light studio on the top floor.
About 1915.
International Film Service, Inc.
Neg ~~ 1573

709314f-b.text:
Sixth Avenue, east side, aorth of Waverly Place, showing two 3-story structures that were formerly No. 80 and 82. The first is reputed to have been at one time "The Allens" a notorius gambling place. The store's last tenent was the wholesale
hotel chinaware firm of R. Seccos and Sons.
View 2 shows the cleared site of this and adjo'ning buildings. The rear tenements are at the back of NOs 58-60 W. 8th St. The "Allen" location would be on the extreme right margin, abuting the side wall of the Van Voorst, the 9-story apartment house
at No. 123-5 Waverly Place.
Overhead appears the distinctive elevation of the apartment dwelling identified as No. 1 Fifth Avenue.
View 1: May 4, 1927
View 2: October 13, 1930
P. L. Sperr
Vie- E1 Ne~EO0
view:2 i N1g. wEO01

724313f-b.text:
(1)
Waverly Place, west from, but no including Gay to Christopher Streets. Prominent building shown, is an apartment house, No. 45 Christopher Street.
May 1, 1933.
P. L Sperr.
(2)
The same, 4lightly westward, showing the triangular Northern Dispensary
at Christopher Street.
May 23, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
An earlier view of the locality seen in No. 2. Buildinga appearing on Christopher Street are Nos. 49 to 41; the 4-story stable being No. 47. These were demolished to form the apartment site shown in
later views.
September 24, 1928.
.. Sperr.

709312f-a.text:
Sixth Avenue, north across Waverly Place, showing at Christopher, W. 8th, Greenwich and Sixth Avenue,the distinctive apartment house, No. 1 Christopher Street, the new Detention House for Women and the Jefferson Market Court. The latter contains the clock tower and appears above the "g1" station at 8th Street. The cleared area in the foreground was necessitated by subway construction. This transportation facility will surplant the old "El" line. Demolition of the
latter will occur in 193S.
View 1: March 15, 1932
View2:  February 24, 1933
P. L. Sperr

709312f-b.text:
Sixth Avenue, north across Waverly Place, showing at Christopher, W. 8th, Greenwich and Sixth Avenue,the distinctive apartment house, No. 1 Christopher Street, the new Detention House for Women and the Jefferson Market Court. The latter contains the clock tower and appears above the "g1" station at 8th Street. The cleared area in the foreground was necessitated by subway construction. This transportation facility will surplant the old "El" line. Demolition of the
latter will occur in 193S.
View 1: March 15, 1932
View2:  February 24, 1933
P. L. Sperr

709317f-a.text:
389-393 Sixth Ave., west side, north of Waverly Place, showing the store fronts of the buildings. Note the sale of Christmas trees in frout
of Kaboolian's Market (No. 389).
December 24, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.

709316f-b.text:
(1)  Sixth Ave., east side, north from Waverly Place, sho ing a clearance at the N.E. corner of Waverly Place. Also seen is the 8th Street station of the Sixth Ave. Elevated Line. Note, in the center of the view, the entrance to the Eighth Ave. Hiunicipally owned Independemt Subway
System.
April 13, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, after further demolition.
June 5, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)  The same, at a later date, and showing on the left, the new Detention House for Women, (at the N.W. corner of Greenwich Ave)., and the
tower of the Jefferson Market Cturt House, adjoining it.
February 7, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

709313f-a.text:
Sixth Ave., west side, north from Waverly Place. The tall building in the background, is the new Detention House for Women, at the N.W. corner of Greenwich Ave., and adjoining it (the building with the clock), is the Jefferson Market Court House. Also note the 8th Street station of the Sixth
Ave. Elevated Line.
March 28, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.

709315f-b.text:
Sixth Avenue, east side, north from Waverly Place to W. 8th Street,showing subway construction shacks. These are grouped at the N. E. corner of Waverly Place. View 2 shows the explosives there. The photographer is viewing westward in th's instance. Note the low buildings on the far side of the Avenue. No. 3 is an earlier
view of the aforementioned corner.
View 1: March 8, 1939
View 2: February 12, 1939
View 3: April 18, 1937
P. L. Sperr

719999f-a.text:
14 and 16 Gay Street, west side, between Waverly Place and Christopher Street. Scotch weavers inhabited Gay Street over a century ago. About 20 years ago the one-block street had the distinction of being the only Negro street in the Washington Square neighborhood. This photo was reproduced on page 100 of the published volume "Changing New York" from which the above data is
an excerpt.
November 16, 1937
Berenice Abbott, photo
Federal Art Project
NWg 2~S
719999f-a.folder: Gay Street & Waverly Place., Manhattan, NY

709318f-a.text: 1. 6th Ave. at n.w. cor. of Waverly Pl. Ne;, A-238 P.L. Sperr, photographer  July 24, 1941

719996f-c.text:
(1)
Gay Street, north from Waverly Place. Gay Street runs only through the block from Waverly Place (originally West 6th Street) to Christopher Street, but the bend in it near the northern end, makes it impossible to see from one end to the other. Gay Street has been spoken of as the shortest street in New York, but it is not -- even Weehawken Street is shorter; however, it is probably
the shortest bent street in Manhattan.
September 25, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, four and a half years later. The new One Christopher Street apartment house, the top of which is seen over the sevenstory loft building in the background, was erected in 1931.
February 24, 1933.
73.z.
P. L. Sperr.  9NG N225
(3)
A view showing No's. 12 to 18 Gay Street, four private dwellings
on the west side of this short thoroughfare.
SSeptember 4, 1938
P. L. Sperr.
